docs.lead_paragraph: AT 9 O'CLOCK ONE RECENT morning, an emergency gong resounded throughout Bellevue Hospital. Members of the medical staff raced through hallways and down littered back stairwells toward the emergency room. "Get them to send some boot covers down from the O.R.!" a doctor called out. The cramped space, crowded with residents yelling and hauling equipment, resembled the engine room of a submarine. Oxygen tanks were piled by the door. Canisters of atropine, a drug used to control muscle spasms, were stacked in metal carts. Everyone donned blue plastic coats, masks with Plexiglas shields, rubber gloves and boot covers, then turned toward the emergency-room door, waiting for casualties to barrel through. This was only a drill. The staff was bracing to treat victims of a simulated sarin-gas attack on the New York subway system like the one that terrified Tokyo last March. Every six months, emergency personnel descend on Bellevue to test the city's response system. Each time the script changes to keep pace with natural disasters and terrorist innovations. In 1993, only minutes after the World Trade Center exploded, the same gong sounded for real as 110 critically injured patients were rushed to the emergency room. During today's drill the staff fell silent as a doctor ran in from the ambulance bay. "Our victims are getting cold," he said. "Can we bring out 10 blankets?"

docs.lead_paragraph: Preliminary tests show that few, if any, baboon bone marrow cells have grown and functioned after being transplanted into a 38-year-old man with severe AIDS, his doctors said yesterday. But the doctors said in interviews that they were puzzled why the patient, Jeff Getty, had done so well since the highly risky experiment was carried out in San Francisco in December. Mr. Getty has gained several pounds, his asthma and a severe case of a skin condition known as seborrhea have cleared up, his immune cells have increased slightly and tests done so far show that he has not developed any infections, said Dr. Steven Deeks, Mr. Getty's doctor at San Francisco General Hospital.

headline.main: Baboon Cells Fail to Thrive, But AIDS Patient Improves

docs.lead_paragraph: The welfare and Medicaid proposals endorsed by the nation's governors this week lack detail and have a long way to go if they are ever to become law. But if approved, such changes would revolutionize social policy by shifting large amounts of money and decision-making power to the states. It is not surprising that governors would recommend changes that enhance their own authority. What is surprising is what they have accepted in exchange: a continuation of many Federal standards and requirements.

headline.main: On Social Policy, Governors Quietly Split the Difference

docs.lead_paragraph: TIME was when every living supertwin -- that means every triplet, quadruplet, quintuplet and sextuplet in the world -- could count on a birthday card from Miss Helen Kirk. In 1939, when Miss Helen, as the Galveston, Tex., dowager always calls herself, was a young medical assistant to a doctor who delivered a set of quadruplets, she began recording multiple births and writing to the parents as a hobby.
